Petitioner: M/s S J S Business Enterprises (P) Ltd.
Legal Principle: A plaintiff who has suppressed a material document is not entitled to relief in any court.
Q1: As a general rule, suppression of a material fact by a litigant disqualifies such litigant from obtaining any relief.
Primary Legal Question: What are the consequences of suppressing material facts in legal proceedings?
Secondary Legal Question: How does the court view litigants who misrepresent or conceal information?
Tertiary Legal Question: What is the impact of approaching the court without full disclosure?

Judges on Bench: V N Khare; S B Sinha
Legal Principle: A plaintiff who has misrepresented facts to the court is not entitled to relief.
Q1: 15. Commission of fraud on court and suppression of material facts are the core issues involved in these matters. Fraud as is well-known vitiates every solemn act. Fraud and justice never dwells together. 16. Fraud is a conduct either by letter or words, which induces the other person, or authority to take a definite determinative stand as a response to the conduct of former either by word or letter. 17. It is also well settled that misrepresentation itself amounts to fraud. Indeed, innocent misrepresentations may also give reason to claim relief against fraud.
Q2: A fraudulent misrepresentation is called deceit and consists in leading a man into damage by willfully or recklessly causing him to believe and act on falsehood. It is a fraud in law if a party makes representations which he knows to be false, and injury ensues therefrom although the motive from which the representations proceeded may not have been bad.
Primary Legal Question: What is the effect of fraud on court proceedings?
Secondary Legal Question: Can an auction sale be set aside due to fraudulent actions by a party?
Tertiary Legal Question: What are the legal remedies available when a party commits fraud upon the court?

Legal Principle: A plaintiff who has suppressed a material document is not entitled to relief in any court.
Q1: We have no hesitation to say that a person, who's case is based on falsehood, has no right to approach the court. He can be summarily thrown out at any stage of the litigation.
Q2: One who comes to the court, must come with clean hands. We are constrained to say that more often than not, process of the court is being abused.
Primary Legal Question: What constitutes fraud on the court in civil litigation?
Secondary Legal Question: What are the consequences of obtaining a decree by withholding vital documents?
Tertiary Legal Question: Is a judgment obtained by fraud considered a nullity?

Laws Referenced: The Waqf Act, 1954; The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
Judges on Bench: R S Sarkaria; N L Untwalia; P S Kailasam
Q1: "A Mutawalli of a waqf although not a trustee in the true sense of the term is still bound by the various obligations of a trustee. He like a trustee or a person standing in a fiduciary capacity cannot advance his own interests or the interests of one class of relations by virtue of the position held by him."
Primary Legal Question: Can a beneficiary claim ownership of property acquired and managed by a Mutawalli under a waqf deed?
Secondary Legal Question: What are the powers and limitations of a Mutawalli in managing waqf properties?
Tertiary Legal Question: How does the court determine the true ownership of property when there is a dispute between a beneficiary and a Mutawalli?

Judges on Bench: P.B. Gajendragadkar; K.N. Wanchoo; K.C. Das Gupta
Q1: A person who is appointed a trustee is not bound to accept the trust, but having once entered upon the trust he cannot renounce the duties and liabilities except with the permission of the Court or with the consent of the beneficiaries or by the authority of the trust deed itself.
Q2: Nor can a trustee delegate his office or any of his duties either to a co-trustee or to a stranger, unless (a) the instrument of trust so provides, or (b) the delegation is in the regular course of business, or (c) the delegation is necessary, or (d) the beneficiary, being competent to contract, consents to the delegation.
Primary Legal Question: Can trustees delegate their duties and powers to another body without explicit authorization?
Secondary Legal Question: What are the legal consequences if trustees abdicate their responsibilities in favor of another entity?
Tertiary Legal Question: Under what circumstances can trustees renounce their duties and liabilities?

Laws Referenced: The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908; The Indian Trusts Act, 1882; The Constitution of India, 1950; The Nizam's Trust Deeds (Validation) Act, 1950
Petitioner: Nawab Shaqafath Ali Khan and others
Respondent: Nawab Imdad Jah Bahadur and others
Legal Principle: Trustees must execute the trust deed strictly per the settlor’s intent.
Q1: "The trustees are bound by the very conditions stipulated in the public trust deed."
Q2: "The terms and conditions originally set out in the public trust cannot be tinkered with by the succeeding trustees, more so, without any permission from the Court concerned."
Q3: "The character of public trusts is that the services mentioned in the deed are to be performed in accordance with the terms and conditions. There cannot be any deviation by the trustees also."
Primary Legal Question: Can a High Court convert a revision application into an appeal under its inherent powers?
Secondary Legal Question: What are the limitations of the High Court's revisional jurisdiction under §115 of the CPC?
Tertiary Legal Question: Under what circumstances can the High Court exercise its inherent powers to convert legal proceedings?

Laws Referenced: The Constitution of India, 1950; The Land Acquisition Act, 1984; The Uttar Pradesh Imposition of Ceiling on Land Holdings Act, 1960
Respondent: State of Uttar Pradesh and others
Judges on Bench: Asok Kumar Ganguly; G S Singhvi
Legal Principle: A plaintiff who has suppressed a material document is not entitled to relief in any court.
Q1: it is now well established that a litigant, who attempts to pollute the stream of justice or who touches the pure fountain of justice with tainted hands, is not entitled to any relief, interim or final.
Q2: conduct of the appellant and his son to mislead the High Court and this Court cannot, but be treated as reprehensible. They belong to the category of persons who not only attempt, but succeed in polluting the course of justice. Therefore, we do not find any justification to interfere with the order under challenge or entertain the appellant's prayer
Primary Legal Question: What are the consequences of suppressing material facts in legal proceedings?
Secondary Legal Question: How does the court view litigants who misrepresent information?
Tertiary Legal Question: What is the impact of approaching the court without clean hands?

Laws Referenced: The Andhra Pradesh Land Grabbing (Prohibition) Act, 1982
Legal Principle: A plaintiff who has suppressed a material document is not entitled to relief in any court.
Q1: It is settled proposition of law that where an applicant gets an order/office by making misrepresentation or playing fraud upon the competent Authority, such order cannot be sustained in the eyes of law.
Q2: 25. Fraud is an intrinsic, collateral act, and fraud of an egregious nature would vitiate the most solemn proceedings of courts of justice. Fraud is an act of deliberate deception with a design to secure something, which is otherwise not due. The expression "fraud" involves two elements, deceit and injury to the person deceived. It is a cheating intended to get an advantage.
Primary Legal Question: Can a person file a review petition after approaching a higher court for the same relief?
Secondary Legal Question: What constitutes abuse of the judicial process in filing multiple petitions?
Tertiary Legal Question: Under what circumstances can a court recall its own order obtained by fraud?

Judges on Bench: V D Tulzapurkar; V Balakrishna Eradi
Legal Principle: A plaintiff who has misrepresented facts to the court is not entitled to relief.
Q1: "It is clear that on 1.10.1982 the petitioners made a false representation to this Court that they were continuing their studies as post-graduate students of Medical College, Rohtak on 1.10.1982 and obtained an order of status quo as of that date to be maintained from this Court."
Q2: "But for the misrepresentation this Court would never have passed the said order."
Q3: But for the misrepresentation, this Court would never have passed the said order. By reason of such conduct, they have disentitled themselves from receiving any relief or assistance from this Court, and the special leave petitions are liable to be dismissed."
Primary Legal Question: Does a person lose the right to relief if they misrepresent facts to the court?
Secondary Legal Question: What are the consequences of making false representations in legal proceedings?
Tertiary Legal Question: How does the court view the suppression of material facts by a litigant?

Q1: In the instant case, defendant no. 1 was the trustee of the property. It was his duty to be faithful to the trust and execute it with reasonable diligence, in the manner in which an ordinary prudent man of business would conduct his own affairs.
Secondary Legal Question: Can a trustee purchase trust property for personal benefit without the consent of the beneficiaries?
Tertiary Legal Question: What are the legal consequences if a trustee benefits personally from the sale of trust property?

Judges on Bench: S. Murtaza Fazal Ali; P.S. Kailasam; A.P. Sen
Q1: The power conferred on the Board of Trustees is no doubt discretionary, but the principle embodied in s. 49 is that when such discretionary power is not exercised reasonably and in good faith, such power may be controlled by a court.”
Secondary Legal Question: Can trustees unilaterally sell trust property without the unanimous consent of all trustees?
Tertiary Legal Question: What are the legal consequences if trustees sell trust property without adhering to the terms of the trust deed?

Laws Referenced: The Uttar Pradesh Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948
Judges on Bench: N.H. Bhagwati; S.K. Das; P.B. Gajendragadkar
Q1: The trustee is thus the legal owner of the trust property and the property vests in him as such. He no doubt holds the trust property for the benefit of the beneficiaries but he does not hold it on their behalf.
Secondary Legal Question: Does §11(1) of the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948, impose tax liability on trustees individually for agricultural income derived from trust-held land?
Tertiary Legal Question: Are trustees considered the primary assessees for agricultural income tax purposes under the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948?
